author: ralexstokes
content: also -- what does everyone like for coordinating testnets? everyone using `docker compose` + manual orchestration? or some other tool(s)???

author: paulhauner
content: We have a bunch of VPS that have SSH access and a bunch of scripts that orchestrate testnet deployment. After the testnet is deployed we're updating them by hand. I originally used scripts for updating and managing them after deployment but I dropped it cause I found it more interesting to see exactly what was happening on each box.

author: paulhauner
content: This works fine for our current setup of 12 nodes, but it won't scale.

author: paulhauner
content: For adding hundreds of nodes to the network, I was thinking of using Amazon ECS.

author: paulhauner
content:
We have this docker-compose environment that goes from nothing to `n` deposited validators and  bn+vc+geth containers. I had intended to use this for large-scale testing.

https://github.com/sigp/lighthouse-docker

author: raulj
content: We've been using k8s for everything at Prylabs for almost 9 months now, including all of our testnet releases, canaries, orchestration, etc.

author: ajsutton
content: We've got an ansible setup for Teku that can spin up EC2 instances and deploy Teku or update things.  It's fairly basic at the moment but still quite useful.

author: paulhauner
content: I think it's probably sensible that teams manage their own infrastructure for multi-client testnets as opposed to unifying them. If we unify I fear we will centralize our efforts on one platform and then end up developing production infrastructure for only one cloud platform/orchestration tool.

author: ajsutton
content: +1  With besu we've wound up with a bunch of solutions and aids for various different deployment approaches so will likely do the same for Teku eventually.  We're just planning an overhaul of our config and CLI so don't want to have to rework all those integrations to adapt to the changes.

author: raulj
content: Agree with Paul here, ideally we shouldn't have to worry about this - we could have some basic orchestration script to spin up multiple nodes from various clients for testing perhaps through docker compose, but for the real multiclient deployment, every team should manage their own infra

author: donschoe
content: Agreed. This will also help maturing the tooling around each client.
